titleStmt.title: Duality-based adaptivity in the hp-nite element method

analytic.title: Duality-based adaptivity in the hp-nite element method

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: In this paper a duality-based a posteriori error analysis is developed for the conforming hp Galerkin nite element approximation of second-order elliptic problems. Duality arguments combined with Galerkin orthogonalty yield representations of the error in arbitrary quantities of interest. From these error estimates, criteria are derived for the simultaneous adaptation of the mesh size h and the polynomial degree p. The effectivity of this procedure is con rmed by numerical tests.

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: This paper deals with the numerical solution of second-order elliptic boundary value problems by the conforming hp-nite element method on tetrahedral or hexahedral meshes. In this Galerkin method the trial and test spaces consist of functions which are globally continuous and locally polynomial with possibly varying degree. Our main objective is to develop criteria for automatic local adaptation of mesh size h as well as polynomial degree p which are oriented by the goal of the computation. Conformity of the approximation is preserved by using 'hanging nodes' and 'local projection'. The a priori analysis of such hp-nite element approximation is well developed (see, e.g., Schwab [11], and the literature cited therein). An a posteriori error analysis following the lines of traditional 'energy-error' estimation was initiated in Babuska and Dorr [2], and has recently been reconsidered in Melenk and Wohlmuth [9] where also hints to further references are given. In this paper, we develop a corresponding analysis for 'goal-oriented' error estimation and adaptivity following the DWR (Dual Weighted Residual) approach described in Becker and Rannacher [5,6] and Bangerth and Rannacher [4].

For simplicity, we concentrate on the Poisson equation with mixed Dirichlet-Neumann boundary conditions, All results of this paper can be extended to more general equations with variable coef cients and other boundary conditions as well as to systems of such equations. Let the goal be to compute a certain output quantity J(u) from the solution u of (1.1) with a prescribed accuracy TOL. Here, we will concentrate on derivative point values and global weighted averages:
div.formula: ¡ Du = f in W; u = 0 on ¶ W D ; ¶ n u = g on ¶ W N (1
J(u) = ¶ i u(a); J(u) = Z W u(x)y(x)dx
div.p: for more examples see [6] and [4]. To the prescribed (linear) functional J(¢), we associate the corresponding 'dual solution' z 2 V determined by the auxiliary problem

where V := fv 2 H 1 (W) : v = 0 on ¶ W D g, and (¢;¢) = (¢;¢) W denoting the usual L 2 -inner product. Some regularization may be required to ensure that J 2 V ¤ . Let u h be the computed solution in some nite element space V p h de ned on a mesh T h with cells K of varying size h K and varying polynomial degree p K . With this notation, the key step of our analysis is the error representation
div.formula: J(u) ¡ J(u h ) = å K2T h © (R h ;z ¡ I p h z) K + (r h ;z ¡ I p h z) ¶ K ª (1.3)
div.p: where R h := R(u h ) and r h := r(u h ) denote the usual equation and normal-jump residuals of u h , and
div.formula: I p h z 2 V p h
div.p: is an arbitrary interpolation. The evaluation of this identity requires guesses of the dual solution z which may be obtained by postprocessing the computed solution z h 2 V p h . This yields an error estimator of the form
div.formula: jJ(u) ¡ J(u h )j º h(u h ) := å K2T h h p K (1.4) with local 'error indicators' h p K > 0. Then, equilibrating these indicators over the mesh T h , h(u h ) º TOL N h ; N h := #fK 2 T h g
div.p: the desired goal h(u h ) º TOL is reached. In this process the decission of how to simultaneously adapt h K and p K is largely based on heuristic arguments. The error estimate (1.4) can also be used to predict quasi-optimal distributions of the mesh size h K and polynomial degree p K in certain interesting special cases. Using the local approximation properties of p-degree polynomials together with local orthogonality arguments, the error estimate (1.4) can be rewritten in the form where F K (h; p) are certain weight factors depending on higher-order derivatives of the primal and dual solutions u and z, respectively. Now, assuming that in the limit TOL ! 0, the distributed quantities F K (h; p) approach a certain limit function F(h; p), depending on the regularity of u and z, the error estimator h(u h ) may be replaced by an integral term
div.formula: h(u h ) = å K2T h h d K h 2p K F K (h; p)
h(u h ) º h(h; p) := Z W h 2p F(h; p; x) dx: (1.5)
div.p: Here, h = h(x) and p = p(x) stand for continuousy distributed mesh-size and polynomial degree functions. Clearly, the above assumption remains largely heuristic since it requires the Galerkin projection to behave locally like the interpolation and the (p+ 1)-order derivatives of the Galerkin approximation u h like those of its limit u. Analogously, the complexity of the approximation, i.e. N h;p := dim(V p h ), can be expressed in the form
div.formula: N(h; p) := Z W p d h ¡ d dx:
div.p: An 'optimal' distribution of h K and p K can now be determined using the calculus of variation. For pure h re nement, with p kept constant, we obtain the formula
div.formula: h(x) = TOL W ´1=d F(x) ¡ 1=(d+2p) ; W := Z W F(p; x) d=(d+2p) dx: (1.6)
div.p: This, in turn yields estimates for the achievable effectivity of h-adaptation based on local indicator equilibration TOL º N ¡ 2 p=d . The task of predicting optimal distributions for simultaneous hp adaptation turns out to be much more dif cult since the quantity h(h; p) depends exponentially on p. However, for certain interesting spe- cial cases, including pointwise error estimation and corner singularities, in which the density function F(h; p) can be expressend in terms of negative powers of certain distance functions,
div.formula: F(h; p) º A 0 r ¡ m 0 0 + A 1 r ¡ m 1 1
div.p: we are able to derive asymptotic formulas for h as well as p. These predictions for 'optimal' distributions of h and p are well con rmed by some numerical tests. The conclusion of our analysis is that the concept of the DWR method for goal-oriented adaptivity is effective also in the context of the hp-nite element method.

div.head: THE hp-FINITE ELEMENT METHOD
div.p: Let T h be decompositions of W into (closed) cells K, triangles or quadrilaterals in 2D, and tetrahedra or hexahedra in 3D, with boundaries ¶ K. The cells are assumed to satisfy the uniform shape condition (see Brenner and Scott [7]), but are allowed to vary in size for local mesh adaptation. In particular, the meshes are not required to be 'conforming', i.e., cells may possess 'hanging' nodes in order to facilitate local

Brought to you by | University of Michigan Authenticated Download Date | 6/22/15 3:35 PM mesh re nement. We set h K := diam(K). Further, to each cell K 2 T h , we associate a parameter p K indicating the local polynomial degree of the trial and test functions on this cell. On the mesh T h , we de ne the nite element space
div.formula: V p h := © v h 2 V : v hjK 2 P(K); K 2 T h ª
div.p: where P(K) is a space of functions which are generated by linear or d-linear transformation from a reference cell K of a space of polynomials P( K) containing the full polynom spaces P p K ( K) in the case of triangles or tetrahedrals, or the full tensorproduct polynom space Q p K ( K) in the case of quadrilaterals or hexahedrals; for details of this construction we refer to the literature, e.g., Babuska and Dorr [2], and Schwab [11]. For practical purposes, we impose the restriction that for neighboring cells K; K 0 the cell-width h and polynomial degree p can only vary within certain limits. Then, the discrete solution u h 2 V p h is determined by
div.formula: (Ñu h ; Ñj h ) = ( f ; j h ) + (g;j h ) ¶ W N 8j h 2 V p h : (2.1)
div.p: In the case of constant distribution of p K , we have the following energy-norm a priori error estimate:
div.formula: kÑ(u ¡ u h )k 6 c p h p kÑ p+1 uk (2.2)
div.p: where c p º 1=p!. Throughout, we use the symbol c for a generic positive constant which may vary with the context, but is always independent of h and p.

div.head: A POSTERIORI ERROR ANALYSIS
div.p: We will now derive a posteriori estimates for the hp-nite element scheme (2.1). Let J 2 V ¤ be an arbitrary (for simplicity linear) functional on V with respect to which the error e = u ¡ u h is to be estimated. Let z 2 V be the associated dual solution de ned by (1.2). Taking j = e as a test function in (1.2), and using Galerkin orthogonality, we obtain the error representation
div.formula: J(e) = (Ñe;Ñz) = (Ñe;Ñ(z¡ y h ))
div.p: for arbitrary y h 2 V p h . Integrating cell-wise by parts, we rewrite this in the form
div.formula: J(e) = å K © (R h ;z¡ y h ) K + (r h ;z¡ y h ) ¶ K ª (3.1)
div.p: with the following notation of cell and edge residuals: where [ ¶ n u h ] denotes the jump of the normal derivative across a cell boundary. In evaluating the error representation (3.1), we choose the special interpolation I p h z 2 V p h for y h . This is locally de ned on each cell K 2 T h by requiring that (I p h z ¡ z)(a) = 0 at vertices a 2 ¶ K (for p > 1), and additionally
div.formula: R hjK := f + Du h ; r hjG := 8 < : 1 2 [ ¶ n u h ]; G » ¶ Kn ¶ W g; G » ¶ W N 0; G » ¶ W D Brought to
Z G (I p h z ¡ z)c ds = 0 8c 2 Q p¡ 2 (G); Z K (I p h z ¡ z)c ds = 0; c 2 Q p¡ 2 (K) on faces G » ¶ K (for p > 2 )
div.p: . From the error representation (3.1), we immediately deduce the following result.
Proposition 3.1. For the error e = u ¡ u h in the hp-nite element scheme (2.1), there holds the a posteriori error estimate
div.formula: J(e) = å K2T n r (1) K w (1) K + r (2) K w (2) K o (3.2)
div.p: with the cell residuals r
K and weight factors w
div.formula: (i) K being de ned by r (1) K = kR h ¡ I p¡ 2 h R h k K ; w (1) K = kz¡ I p h zk K r (2) K = h ¡ 1=2 K kr h ¡ I p¡ 2 h r h k ¶ K ; w (2) K = h 1=2 K kz¡ I p h zk ¶ K :
div.p: Theorem 3.1 provides a posteriori estimates for arbitrary functionals of the error. However, splitting the contribution from the cell-residuals R h from that of the face-residuals r h usually causes severe overestimation of the error. Therefore, we prefer to directly use the error representation (3.1) as the basis for error control. Its evaluation requires us to generate approximations to the dual solution z with accuracy better than that of the simple Ritz projection z h 2 V p h obtained from
div.formula: (Ñj h ; Ñz h ) = J(j h ) 8j h 2 V p h :(3.3)
div.p: This is usually obtained by post-processing z h using local higher-order interpolation or defect correction. Numerical experience shows that, at least for standard elliptic problems, this approximation is not critical for the method. Let the post-processed approximation to z be denoted by zh . Then the error is controlled by the error estimator
div.formula: h w (u h ) := ¯å K2T © (R h ; zh ¡ I p h zh ) K + (r h ; zh ¡ I p h zh ) ¶ K ª ¯(3.4)
div.p: while the adaptation process is driven by the local error indicators
div.formula: h K := ¯(R h ; zh ¡ I p h zh ) K + (r h ; zh ¡ I p h zh ) ¶ K ¯: (3.5)
div.p: Our numerical tests indicate that the estimator h w (u h ) is indeed asymptotically sharp as TOL ! 0.

div.head: The adaptation process
div.p: On the basis of the a posteriori error estimator h(u h ) in (3.4) and the resulting local error indicators h K , 'optimal' distributions of h K and p K are constructed by a series of adaptation cycles such that at the nal stage the equilibration property
div.formula: h K º TOL N h ; N h = #fK 2 T opt g (3.6)
div.p: is achieved. Here, we follow standard adaptation strategies described in the literature, e.g., Ainsworth and Senior [1], Oden, Patra and Feng [10], and Melenk and Wohlmuth [9]. Let a tolerance TOL be given. In solving a stationary problem the adaptation process usually starts from a coarse mesh T (0) h ; k = 1;2; :: : , with mesh-size distribution h (0) and minimum polynomial degree p (0) ² 1. Then, a sequence of meshes T (k) h ; k = 1;2; :: : , with corresponding distributions h
div.formula: (k) K and p (k)
div.p: K is constructed by the following process:
(1) On the current mesh
div.formula: T (k) h compute u (k) h and z (k) h , and evaluate h w (u (k) h ) and the cell-error indicators h K . If h(u (k) h ) < TOL, then STOP.
div.p: (2) Order cells according to the size of h K . On each cell K 2 T (k)
div.formula: h for N h = #fK 2 T (k) h g test whether h K < 1 2 TOL N h ?
div.p: If YES, proceed to next cell. If NO, consider the following three cases:

°Cell K and the polynomial degree p K had been left unchanged in the preceding cycle. Then, leave K again unchanged but increase p K to p K + 1. °Cell K had been left unchanged in the preceding cycle, but p K had been increased. Check whether
div.formula: h K < h K h old K :
div.p: If YES, then again increase p K to p K + 1. If NO, then re ne K into 2 d cells. °Cell K had been obtained by re nement of a mother cell K m 2 T (k¡ 1) h (without changing the polynomial degree). Check whether (3) Usually the local changes of h K and p K cause additional hanging nodes and discontinuity of functions. In order to restore conformity (in the sense de ned above), some neighboring cells need to be re ned and their polynomial degree raised.
div.formula: h K 6 2 ¡ p K h old K m ? If YES,
div.p: We note that in this adaptation process, we try to raise p K whenever possible. The philosophy underlying this rule is that usually for enhancing accuracy on a cell K it is more economical to raise p K rather than to reduce h K .

div.head: Mesh optimization
div.p: The information contained in the error estimate (3.4) may be used directly to construct 'optimal' h and p distributions for which the required error tolerance TOL is achieved at minimal cost. However, this ambitious goal turns out to be almost impracticable as it requires super-accurate information on the dual solution z which is rarely available on the current meshes. Therefore, we will use the error representation (3.1) only as basis of a heuristic argument for predicting the complexity of hp adaptation in certain special cases. A mesh T h = fKg is characterized by a distributed mesh-size function h, such that h jK º h K . Correspondingly, the degree p K of the local nite element Ansatz on cell K is described in terms of a distributed degree function p such that p jK º p K . Motivated by the local approximation behaviour of hp-nite element interpolation (see Schwab [11]), we assume that the terms in the error representation behave like
div.formula: jR(u h ) ¡ I p¡ 2 h R(u h )j º min 26m6 p+1 ½ h m¡ 2 K maxfp m¡ 2 ; (m ¡ 2)!g jÑ m uj ¾ (3.7) jr(u h ) ¡ I p¡ 2 h r(u h )j º min 26m6 p+1 ½ h m¡ 2 K maxfp m¡ 2 ; (m ¡ 2)!g jÑ m uj ¾ (3.8)
div.p: where I ¡ 1 h R(u h ) := 0, and
div.formula: z ¡ I p h z º min 06m6 p+1 ½ h m K maxfp m ; m!g jÑ m zj ¾ : (3.9)
div.p: The rigorous justi cation of these estimates, particularly of replacing the Ritz projection u h by the continuous solution u, is far beyond the scope of this paper. These relations suggest to replace the discrete error representation (3.1) by a continuous analogue of the form
div.formula: J(e) º h(h; p) := Z W h(x) 2p(x) F(h; p)(x) dx (3.10)
div.p: with a certain function F(h; p). We assume that F > 0, i.e., we exclude the exceptional case that primal or dual solutions locally coincide with a polynomial of degree p. The function F(h; p) may have strong singularities which will force the mesh-size h(x) to develop a very heterogeneous behavior as TOL ! 0.
For varying p(x), we denote by N h;p the number of degrees of freedoms in the nite element space V p h :
div.formula: N h;p º å K2T h p d K º N(h; p) := Z W h(x) ¡ d p(x) d dx: (3.11)
div.p: We take this quantity as a measure for the complexity of the discretization.

div.head: Optimization of h for p xed
div.p: At rst, we consider the simple case of constant polynomial degree p > 1, i.e., only the mesh size h is allowed to be varied for satisfying the error tolerance TOL. Further, the density function F(h; p) is supposed to be independent of h, of the form
div.formula: F(x) = jÑ p+1 u(x)
(x) = W ¡ 1=d F(x) ¡ 1=(d+2p) TOL 1=d (3.14) provided that W := R W F(x) d=(d+2p) dx < ¥.
div.p: The achievable mesh complexity is given by
div.formula: N h := dim(V p h ) º p d W (d+2p)=2p TOL ¡ d=2p : (3.15)
div.p: Proof. (i) At rst, we determine possible optimal solutions by employing the classical Euler-Lagrange approach. We introduce the Lagrangian L(h; l ) = N(h) + l fh(h) ¡ TOLg with an unknown parameter l 2 R. Notice that p is kept xed. Then, any optimal mesh-size function h corresponds to stationary point fh;l g of L. Differentiation L with respect to h and l , yields the necessary optimality conditions
div.formula: ¡ dh ¡ d¡ 1 p d + l 2ph 2p¡ 1 F ² 0; Z W h 2p F dx ¡ TOL = 0:
div.p: Clearly l > 0, since h > 0 and F > 0. We conclude that

Clearly, the so determined pair fh;l g is the only stationary point of L(h; l ).
(ii) Next, we show that h is actually a solution of the mesh optimization problem.
For any admissible mesh-size function h > 0, there holds (by use of H ölder's inequality with r = (d + 2p)=d and s = r=(r ¡ 1)

div.p: and consequently,
div.formula: N(h) > W (d+2p)=2p TOL ¡ d=2p p d :
div.p: This gives us a lower bound on the optimal value. The proof is completed by showing that this lower bound is actually attained by h :
div.formula: N(h) = Z W h ¡ d p d dx = Z W (W ¡ 1 TOL) ¡ d=2p F d=(2p+d) p d dx = W d=2p TOL ¡ d=2p W p d : Remark 3.1.
div.p: Alternatively to the optimization problem (3.13), we can also consider h(h; p) ! min, under the constraints N(h; p) = N max ; h > 0, which has the solution h
div.formula: (x) = W 1=d N ¡ 1=d max F(x) ¡ 1=(2p+d) .
div.p: Remark 3.2. In two dimensions and for bilinear elements, i.e. for d = 2 and p = 1, the formula for the 'optimal' mesh complexity reduces to N º W 2 TOL ¡ 1 , provided that sup TOL!0 W < ¥. This is the case even for rather 'irregular' functionals J(¢) including the evaluation of J(u) = ¶ 2 i u(a) as limit case.
div.formula: d p d¡ 1 h ¡ (2p+d) F ¡ 1 ² l ² 1 2 d p d¡ 1 (W ¡ 1 TOL) ¡ (2p+d)=2p
div.p: and the relation
div.formula: N h = p ¡ d N(h; p) = W (2p+d)=2p TOL ¡ d=2p = (TOL ¡ 1 W ) (2p+d)=2p TOL
div.p: imply that the optimal mesh-size distribution is characterized by the equilibration property
div.formula: h 2p+d F ² p d¡ 1 l ¡ 1 = (W ¡ 1 TOL) (2p+d)=2p = N ¡ 1 TOL: (3.16)
div.p: Hence, the strategy of equilibrating the local error indicators h K in the error estima- tor (3.4), as used in the error-balancing strategy, seems justi ed.

div.head: Simultaneous optimization of h and p
div.p: Next, we consider the more complicated case of spatially varying polynomial degree p(x). To simplify the analysis, we have to assume certain properties for the derivatives of the primal and dual solutions such as they are to be expected in prototypical situations. We restrict us to the two-dimensional case. Since it can be expected that the local hp adaptation will be determined by the essential singularities in the primal solution u and the dual solution z, we concentrate on the extreme cases of point value evaluation and corner singularities. Some aspects of this analysis have already been developed in Scott and Rannacher [12].
For computing the solution of the optimization problem
div.formula: N(h; p) ! min; h(h; p) = TOL; h > 0; p > 0 (3.17)
div.p: we again employ the Euler-Lagrange formalism, while the existence of a solution is assumed to be guaranteed. The Lagrangian is de ned by
div.formula: L(h; p; l ) := N(h; p) + l © h(h; p) ¡ TOL ª
div.p: with a scalar l 2 R. Taking derivatives of L(h; p; l ) with respect to h, p and l , we obtain for arbitrary variations fj; y; mg of fh; p;l g the optimality conditions This implies the pointwise relations
div.formula: L 0 h (h; p; l ) = Z W © ¡ dh ¡ d¡ 1 p d + l ¡ 2ph 2p¡ 1 F + h 2p F 0 h ¢ª j dx = 0 L 0 p (h; p; l ) = Z W © dh ¡ d p d¡ 1 + l h 2p ¡ ln(h 2 )F + F 0 p ¢ª y dx = 0 L 0 l (h; p; l ) = ½ Z W h 2p F dx ¡ TOL ¾ m = 0 Brought to
¡ dh ¡ d¡ 1 p d + l ¡ 2ph 2p¡ 1 F + h 2p F 0 h ¢ = 0 (3.18) dh ¡ d p d¡ 1 + l h 2p ¡ ln(h 2 )F + F 0 p ¢ = 0 (3.19) Z W h 2 p F dx ¡ TOL = 0 (3.20)
div.p: to be satis ed by any optimal triple fh; p; l g. The rst two of these equations can be simpli ed to
From these equations, we infer that l 6 = 0 (in fact l > 0 ), and therefore adding them yields
div.formula: 2F + hp ¡ 1 F 0 h + 2ln(h)F + F 0 p = 0: (3.23) Assuming that 2F + hp ¡ 1 F 0 h 6 = 0, this is rewritten in the form 1 + ln(h) + F 0 p ¡ ln(h)hp ¡ 1 F 0 h 2F + hp ¡ 1 F 0 h = 0
div.p: and taking exponentials,
div.formula: h = 1 e exp F 0 p ¡ ln(h)hp ¡ 1 F 0 h 2F + hp ¡ 1 F 0 h ´: (3.24)
div.p: Further, from (3.21), we obtain
div.formula: l = dh ¡ 2 p¡ d p d¡ 1 2F + hp ¡ 1 F 0 h (3.25)
div.p: and, consequently,

From these equations for particular cases of F(h; p), we will compute h and p, while l is determined using additionally the constraint (3.20). This stationary point fh; p; l g of L is then assumed to actually be a solution of the hp optimization problem. In contrast to the special situation of Proposition 3.2, the proof of this must be left open in the general case. In the presence of a reentrant corner x 1 2 ¶ W with inner angle w > p, in general, the solution contains a leading 'corner singularity' of the form s 1 (r; J) = r a sin(Ja), with r = jx ¡ x 1 j and a = p=w, and fr;J g denoting polar coordinates at x 1 . Hence, we assume that u behave just like this singular function:
jÑ q u(x)j º q!jx ¡ x 1 j a¡ q :
In this case the dual solution is smooth but also contains the component r a . Hence, the singular behaviour of F is described by
div.formula: F(h; p)(x) = s (x) 2(a¡ p¡ 1) ; s(x) := jx ¡ x 1 j: (3.27) Proposition 3.3.
div.p: Let the weight function F(h; p) be given by (3.27), with some a > 1=2. Then, the solution of the hp optimization problem has the following prop- erties:
The complexity of the resulting discretization is N º ln(TOL ¡ 1 ) 2 .

div.p: Since W (r) is monotone with W (r) º ln(r) for large r, and TOL ¡ 1 ¾ 1, this equation determines l > 0 and hence also p. With B 1 := fx 2 W; 2l e ¡ 2 s(x) 2a < 1g, we obtain TOL º
div.formula: Z B 1 s 2(a¡ 1) dx + 1 2 l ¡ 1 e 2 Z WnB 1 s ¡ 2 dx:
div.p: From this we infer that l º TOL ¡ 1 . To estimate the complexity N, we recall that
div.formula: N º Z W h ¡ 2 p 2 dx º Z B 1 l 2 s 4a¡ 2 dx + Z WnB 1 s ¡ 2 ln(2e ¡ 2 l s 2a ) 2 dx which implies N º ln(TOL ¡ 1 ) 2 .
div.p: Remark 3.4. The remarkable fact, that the optimal mesh-size distribution h º jx ¡ x 1 j does not depend on the exponent a is in agreement with a priori interpola- tion results (see Schwab [11]). Further, the strategy of equilibrating the local error indicators h K used in our adaptation process is justi ed. Indeed, we have
div.formula: h w (u h ) º Z W h 2p s 2(a¡ p¡ 1) dx º å K2T h h 2p K +2 K s 2(a¡ p K ¡ 1) K º å K2T h e ¡ 2 p s 2a

div.head: Gradient point values of smooth solution.
div.p: Next, we consider the case of evaluation of gradient point-values Ñu(x 0 ), corresponding to smooth data and regular domain W. In this case we expect, based on results of a priori analysis, that the most economical way to achieve high pointwise accuracy is to keep h xed and to only increase p. This should also be the result of the automatic adaptation process based on the error estimate jJ(e)j º h(h; p). In order to achieve this, we would like to use the error representation h(h; p) := This seems too dif cult as the corresponding function F(h; p) is not differentiable. Therefore, we try to mimic this behavior by using the weight function (3.32). Then, the solution of the hp optimization problem has the following properties:
div.formula: F(h; p)(x) = s (x)

div.p: To determine l , we recall the constraint (3.20). Setting W 0 := fx 2 W; jx ¡ x 0 j 6 1g and W 1 := fx 2 W; jx ¡ x 0 j > 1g, and using the results for h and p, we obtain
div.formula: TOL = Z W h 2p s ¡ 2¡ p dx º Z W 0 e 2¡ p dx + Z W 1 e ¡ 2p s ¡ 2 dx º l ¡ 1 Z W 0 e 2 dx + 1 2 l ¡ 1 Z W 1 jx ¡ x 0 js ¡ 2 dx:

div.formula: N = Z W h ¡ 2 p 2 dx º ln(TOL ¡ 1 ) 2 :

div.head: NUMERICAL TEST
div.p: In the following, we describe the results of some computational experiments in order to verify the predictions made in Propositions 3.4 and 3.3 for the 'optimal' distributions of spatial mesh-size h and polynomial degree p. The con guration for this test is chosen as shown in Fig. 1. The computational domain is W = (¡ 1; 1) £ (¡ 1; 3) possibly with a vertical slit with tip at (0; 0). The error J(e) is estimated by the error estimator h w := h w (u h ) which is eval- uated by the procedure described above. The local adaptation of h and p is done on the basis of the corresponding local error indicators h K de ned in (3.5) using the heuristic strategy as described above. The initial mesh consists of N 0 = 45 cells. For the purpose of this particular test, we did not go for maximum ef ciency, but rather iterated on each adaptation level as long as necessary in order to achieve satisfactory equilibration of the indicators h K over the mesh. The quality of the error estimate is expressed as usual in terms of the 'effectivity index'
div.formula: I eff := jh w (u h )=J(e)j:
div.p: Further, we monitor the number of degrees of freedom N := dimV p h , the actual error J w = J w (e) obtained by our method, and the error J E = J E (e) obtained by using a standard energy-type error estimator (see Melenk and Wohlmuth [9]):
div.formula: h E (u h ) := µ å K2T h h 2 K p ¡ 2 K k f + Du h k 2 K + 1 2 h K p ¡ 1 K k[ ¶ n u h ]k 2 ¶ K ¶ 1=2 : Brought to

div.head: The 'semi-singular' case
div.p: On the domain W 0 = (¡ 1; 1) £ (¡ 1; 3), we compute the derivative point value J(u) := ¶ 1 u(x 0 ) at x 0 = (0:5; 2:5). The solution is u(x) = sin(p(x 1 + 1)=2)sin(3p(x 2 + 1)=4):

As expected the automatic adaptation process keeps the initial mesh unre ned and only raises p. Table 1 shows that for computing point values, h p adaptivity based on the weighted error estimator h w is more ef cient than that using the energy error estimator h E . Further, the estimator h w seems to be asymptotically sharp, i.e., I eff ! 1 as TOL ! 0. Also the complexity N º ln(TOL ¡ 1 ) 2 is well con rmed.
Figure 1 shows the predicted decay of p away from the point x 0 enforced by the weighted error indicators.

div.head: The fully singular case
div.p: On the slit domain W 1 = (¡ 1;1) £ (¡ 1;3) n fx 2 R; x 1 = 0; ¡ 1 < x 2 < 0g de ned above, we compute the derivative point value J(u) := ¶ 1 u(x 0 ). The exact solution is u(x) = r 1=2 sin(J=2)(x 1 ¡ 1)(x 1 + 1)(x 2 ¡ 3)(x 2 + 1). Table 2 indicates that the error estimator h w is asymptotically sharp and more ef cient for computing the point value ¶ 1 u(P) than h E . Further the complexity seems to be N º ln(TOL ¡ 1 ) 2 . The meshes shown in Figs. 2 and 3 con rm that the mesh-size behavior is h º jx ¡ x 1 j as predicted, independet on TOL and p. Finally, Figure 4 shows a comparison of the ef ciency of hp adaptation driven by the weighted error estimator h w and the plain energy-error estimator h E for the two test cases.
